image.alt: Exterior of Sekijima Orthodontics office in Renton

paragraphs.text: Open communication with parents and patients is vital to effective orthodontic care. We want our patients and their families to feel comfortable in all aspects of their treatment and encourage them to ask questions throughout their orthodontic treatment with us.

We value honesty and integrity in all that we do, and treat each person as we would want to be treated. We truly enjoy what we do—creating beautiful smiles. We appreciate that our patients have chosen us for their orthodontic needs.

paragraphs.text: Dr. Robert Sekijima has been practicing orthodontics in the Renton Highlands since 1988. A Bellevue native, he earned his BA and dental degrees from the University of Washington and completed orthodontic specialty training and a Masters in Oral Biology at the University of Missouri. He enjoys hiking, skiing, mission trips, and family time.

Dr. Bill Wan graduated from the University of Washington School of Dentistry and completed specialty training at the University of Colorado, Denver. He brings digital scanning, advanced treatment planning, and aligner therapy to the practice, and is American Board of Orthodontics certified.

image.alt: Dr. Robert Sekijima, orthodontist at Sekijima Orthodontics

paragraphs.text: We offer a full range of orthodontic services — traditional braces, expanders, specialty appliances, and aligner therapy — tailored to patients of all ages.

Aligner therapy including Invisalign-style clear aligners

paragraphs.text: Open communication and patient education are central to our care — we make sure parents and patients understand treatment options and expected outcomes.
We value honesty and integrity, treat each person with respect, and work to create beautiful, healthy smiles for patients of all ages.
Free initial consultation and personalized treatment planning to help you choose the best path forward for your smile.
Gentle, evidence-based orthodontic care with emphasis on patient comfort and clear communication throughout treatment.

Dr. Sekijima has been practicing orthodontics in the Renton Highlands since 1988. He earned his Bachelor of Arts and Dental degrees from the University of Washington and received his Orthodontic specialty training at the University of Missouri where he also earned a Masters in Oral Biology.

A longtime practice owner and community-minded clinician, Dr. Sekijima has taken biannual mission trips to Central America and Southeast Asia since 2005. He and his team bring decades of experience and a patient-first approach to every treatment plan.

Dr. Bill Wan joined Sekijima Orthodontics bringing digital scanning, aligner therapy (Invisalign<sup>®</sup>), and contemporary treatment planning. He graduated from the University of Washington School of Dentistry and completed specialty training at the University of Colorado, Denver.
As an American Board of Orthodontics certified orthodontist, Dr. Wan is committed to high-quality, patient-centered care and modern treatment workflows that improve comfort and outcomes.

og_meta.title: About Sekijima Orthodontics
og_meta.description: Meet our doctors and team — delivering patient-focused orthodontic care and community service since 1988.

image.alt: Smiling family welcomed at Lakeshore Orthodontics front desk

paragraphs.text: There is never a charge for your initial consultation. The initial consultation includes a comprehensive examination, a panorex x‑ray, review of the clinical diagnosis, and a detailed discussion by Dr. Sekijima of your treatment options with the benefits of each. Dr. Sekijima will also estimate treatment time, costs, and type of braces or other orthodontic appliances. For your convenience, if treatment is indicated, diagnostic records can often be taken on the same day. These records include digital facial and dental photos, digital x‑rays, and plaster study models. The appointment to place appliances (expander, headgear, space maintainer, or braces) usually takes 30–90 minutes. You will then be seen at intervals 1–8 weeks apart for adjustments (10–20 minutes).
Bring completed patient forms (PDFs available below), bring your insurance information if applicable, and expect records (photos/x‑rays) and a treatment discussion during your visit.

image.alt: Father with daughter at reception of dentist's surgery

paragraphs.text: If your insurance covers orthodontic treatment, you will receive reduced personal costs. Most policies have a lifetime maximum orthodontic benefit different from regular dental insurance. Policies vary; the practice will review your insurance and help determine benefits. If insurance requires verification of continuing treatment, the office will notify them; sometimes forms will be sent to you to sign and return. If benefits change during treatment, the financially responsible party is accountable for charges.

Treatment cost depends on complexity and length. The practice offers flexible payment options: an in‑house financing plan with an interest‑free monthly payment schedule after a down payment, acceptance of Visa/MasterCard, handling of medical savings/flex plans, and a cash pre‑payment discount.

Please download and print the forms below and bring them to your first visit (PDFs provided). The office currently uses downloadable PDF intake forms — there are no online submission endpoints listed on the site files provided.

image.alt: Patient filling out orthodontic health history forms online

seo.page_description: Start your journey to a confident smile with Sekijima Orthodontics. Learn what to expect on your first visit, download new‑patient forms, and schedule a consult
seo.page_keywords: orthodontics, first visit, new patient forms, financing, Sekijima Orthodontics

og_meta.title: Get Started | Sekijima Orthodontics
og_meta.description: Start your journey to a confident smile with Sekijima Orthodontics. Learn what to expect on your first visit, download new‑patient forms, and schedule a consult

image.alt: Exterior of Sekijima Orthodontics office building

paragraphs.text: By age 7 many children have a mix of baby and permanent teeth and subtle problems with jaw growth or tooth eruption can be identified. Early detection lets the orthodontist guide jaw growth, reduce trauma risk to protruded front teeth, correct harmful oral habits, and guide permanent teeth into more favorable positions. Early treatment can sometimes prevent more complex problems later or shorten later treatment.

Key benefits include guiding jaw growth and facial development, lowering the risk of trauma to front teeth, correcting habits like thumb‑sucking or abnormal swallowing, and helping permanent teeth erupt into better positions.

image.alt: Space maintainer (lingual arch) appliance used in early treatment

paragraphs.text: Orthodontic treatment is a viable option for almost any adult. It can restore function, improve bite and appearance, and enhance self‑confidence.

Special coordination with your dentist or periodontist may be necessary for complex restorative needs; bone loss can affect the direction and amount of tooth movement and may require additional care. It's never too late to consider orthodontic care.

image.alt: Sekijima Orthodontics team and patient-friendly office environment

Treatments.title: Braces — How they work & what to expect

paragraphs.text: Braces are brackets bonded to teeth connected by archwires that apply gentle, controlled forces to move teeth into proper positions. Additional appliances (elastics/rubber bands, headgear, expanders) may be used when needed to correct bite or guide jaw growth.

Good oral hygiene and cooperation—following diet and appliance wear instructions—are key to efficient treatment and optimal results. Typical treatment length is generally 1–3 years depending on case severity and cooperation.

Care tips: brush thoroughly at least twice daily, floss with floss‑threaders, avoid hard or sticky foods (ice, nuts, popcorn, whole apples/carrots) and minimize sugar‑sweetened drinks. If something breaks, contact the office to arrange repairs and save any broken pieces.

image.alt: Elastics and rubber bands used with braces

Treatments.title: Clear Aligners (Invisalign<sup>®</sup> and other aligner therapy)

paragraphs.text: The practice has incorporated digital scanning, treatment planning, and aligner therapy, including Invisalign<sup>®</sup>, as part of modern treatment offerings. Digital workflows allow customized aligner treatment for appropriate cases.
If aligners are recommended, the team will explain the process, expected wear schedule, and how aligners fit into an overall treatment plan so you know what to expect at each stage.

image.alt: Clear aligners and orthodontic products used in modern aligner therapy

Treatments.title: Orthognathic (Corrective Jaw) Surgery — when it's needed

paragraphs.text: A severe jaw growth discrepancy may require coordinated orthodontics and corrective jaw surgery once facial growth is complete, although this is relatively rare. For some jaw joint or muscle complaints (TMJ pain, bruxism) an orthodontist can help diagnose the problem and advise on next steps.
Your orthodontist will discuss timing, goals, and any needed surgical referrals as part of comprehensive care, coordinating closely with surgeons when surgery is recommended.

image.alt: Orthodontic consultation and coordinated surgical planning

Treatments.title: Retainers — keeping your smile in place

paragraphs.text: After braces or aligner treatment, retainers are needed to stabilize teeth until bone and gums adapt. For the first year retainers are typically worn full‑time except for eating and brushing; many patients then transition to night‑time wear for long‑term maintenance.
We offer both removable and fixed options and provide guidance on proper retainer care and follow‑up so your results last.

image.alt: Retainer lab work and patient resources

paragraphs.text: We maintain comprehensive digital records—facial and dental photos, digital x‑rays, and study models—to support accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. These records help track progress and communicate goals at every stage.
We take digital facial and dental photos, digital x‑rays, and study models to create a complete record used for diagnosis and custom treatment planning.

image.alt: Digital records and orthodontic imaging tools

paragraphs.text: Digital scanning and 3D planning enable precise aligner workflows and more predictable outcomes, allowing us to simulate stages of tooth movement and improve communication about treatment objectives.
We use a variety of appliances—expanders, space maintainers, elastics, and custom lab work for retainers and appliances—when indicated. Appliance care instructions are provided with each device.

image.alt: Modern digital orthodontic technology in the clinic

image.alt: Patient smiling with orthodontic braces in our Emeryville office

paragraphs.text: Find answers to common questions about braces, appliances, scheduling, and downloadable new‑patient forms at Sekijima Orthodontics.

accordion.header: Is it normal to have discomfort?

paragraphs.text: It's normal to have discomfort for three to five days after braces or retainers are adjusted. Although temporary, it can make eating uncomfortable. Encourage soft foods, rinse with warm salt water, and over‑the‑counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen may help.

accordion.header: How do I take care of my braces?

paragraphs.text: Extra time is needed for brushing to get around brackets and wires. Specialized brushes and floss‑threaders help remove plaque. Vigorously brush at least twice daily until teeth are spotlessly clean to avoid inflamed gums, decalcification, bad breath, or tooth decay.

Avoid hard or sticky items such as ice, nuts, popcorn kernels, hard candy (Starburst, Skittles, Jolly Ranchers), caramel, jerky, whole apples/carrots (cut them), hard bread crusts, and avoid chewing pens/pencils/fingernails. You may chew sugarless gum. Minimize sugary drinks and snacks.

If any portion of an appliance breaks, call the office so arrangements can be made for repairs. Try to save broken pieces and bring them with you when possible so we can evaluate and fix the issue quickly.

accordion.header: Can I play sports while wearing braces?

paragraphs.text: Yes — a protective mouth guard is advised for contact sports. Our office can supply a mouth guard; avoid boil‑and‑bite guards if advised otherwise. A guard protects your lips, cheeks, and appliance during impact.

accordion.header: Will braces interfere with playing musical instruments?

paragraphs.text: Wind and brass instruments may require an adjustment period, but with practice most musicians adapt and continue to play effectively. If needed, we can suggest techniques to reduce discomfort while you adjust.
Yes. Today's brackets are smaller and clear brackets are an option to reduce visibility. Clear or ceramic brackets and discreet treatment options can make orthodontic care less noticeable.

accordion.header: Am I too old for braces?

paragraphs.text: Orthodontic treatment is a viable option for most adults. Many adults choose treatment to improve function and appearance. In some cases special periodontal or dental care may be necessary — we'll review this at your consultation.

accordion.header: How can I schedule an appointment?

paragraphs.text: Scheduling is easy — call us at (425) 235‑4830 or visit our online appointments page. We’ll find a convenient time that fits your family’s needs and provide instructions for new‑patient forms.
